text: Keg at the brewery. Black, thin creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of chocolate, wheat, coffee, caramel, pepper. Taste is caramel, coffee, green pepper, roast. A bit thin.
A solid coffee beer. thick black hue, looks like a real coffee. strong roasty coffee aromas and flavor. a great brunch beer!!

12 ounce bottle from Woodmans in Janesville, WI, served at cellar temperature in an Ayinger weizen glass. Big smooth dark tan head fills much of the glass and wont go away; when it finally recedes a totally opaque blackness can be seen...coffee unquestionably dominates the nose, dark-roasty coffee, but some weizenbock character does emerge with time, a bit of caramelized banana, clove and sourdough showing up, though always struggling for a place with the java....on the tongue, sweet and caramel-like at first, but with a somewhat rough tartness and a bit of alcohol coming in quickly, and coffee bitterness dominating the long finish...very smooth on the tongue, full and velvety-creamy, with just enough carbonation to sparkle a touch. Interesting concoction that works for the most part - far and away the best thing Ive had from this brewery so far.

Having this beer when its a little old and the coffee characteristics suffer from it. Aroma is good but no coffee. Flavor has the coffee showing up but not so much like fresh coffee.. Body is good though personally I would have preferred it a bit softer from the crisp carbonation.
Bottle thanks to Bytemesis poured dark cola brown with a beige head and nice lacing. Aromas of caramel malt, lactose, chocolate, and vanilla. Flavor is mild bitter sweet.

Bottle. Pours deep black, small beige head, good lacing. Aroma of coffee, roasty malt, anise. Flavor is light sweet, CV light bitter, mega coffee, roasty. Lingering bitterness, bit of ashtray. Medium body.

Taste: Deep dark semi sweet malts, dark bread, complex, dry coffee finish, hint of chocolate malts and dark fruits as well. Big roasted coffee nose. Black opaque with a tan tall foamy head with a decent lattice. Full body, good after dinner meal.

Pours a dark brown color with khaki colored head. Coffee, dark roasted coffee, light cocoa, and some bread notes on the nose; follows onto the palate. Medium to full bodied. Finishes with roasted coffee and bread.

Bottle courtesy of nuplastikk, thank you sir! Opaque black color, thin brown head. Nice aroma of earthy coffee grounds and malted milk balls. Taste has Caffe au lait, ovaltine, dark fruit at the finish. Smooth full body. Delicious.

Imperial wheat coffee ale.  
コーヒー、し&

12 oz bottle poured into Moeder Lambic glass on Christmas Day after a big prime rib dinner. Im going into this with an open mind despite the fact coffee is not a big selling point for me in a beer. Dark black colored ale with minor (and mildly disappointing) tannish head. Nose is more subdued than anticipated but the coffee, roasted malt, and chocolate characteristics are present. Everything about this one proclaims coffee. Roasted malts, nutty qualities, full on mouthfeel, subtle undercurrent of dark chocolate. Slightly thinner than other coffee efforts which falls in line with the fact its a wheat coffee ale and not a coffee stout. If you love coffee, you should meet this "Joe". For me, its not really in my wheelhouse. I can appreciate but Ill likely have to find a taker for the remaining bottle I have left.

Pours black with a medium khaki head with excellent retention. AROMA: rich malt, freshly ground coffee, chocolate, roasty, herbs, spice, floral, herbal hops, smoke, vanilla, slight soy sauce and earthy. TASTE: rich malt, freshly ground coffee, chocolate, roasty, herbs, spice, floral, hop spice, smoke, tannins, vanilla, slight soy sauce, peppercorn, oatmeal and earthy. AFTER TASTE: malty, smoke/char, coffee and spice with a thick rich coffee finish.

12oz bottle from Casanova in Hudson on a Sunday with commonmac. Coffee and chocolate nose. Nice creamy body. Maybe some subtle vanilla. Chocolate coffee taste with nice finish. Solid. Nice to meet you joe.

Bottle. Black pour with a brown head. Aroma starts very bitter and roasty, some coffee and dark chocolate notes, more sweetness as it warms with some maraschino cherry. Flavour is surprisingly rich, some sweet wheat malt coming through with coffee notes and chocolate, hints of citrus and a little spicy when cold giving way to sweet fruit as it warms. Really interesting brew, and pretty tasty.
I like Alterra and I like Three Sheeps. The combination works really well as one may expect. Maybe I will try heating some up in a mug tomorrow morning.

Coffee hits the front, not the back of the tongue, which makes me think of coffee grounds rather than good coffee. Frothy palate, yucky finish. The man serving it suggested that this batch is nearing the end; could be better when fresher. (At Summer Beer Dabbler, St. Paul, MN)

On tap at Old Fashioned pours a deep black with a thin layer of beige head. Nose has burnt malt/wheat chaff, molasses, licorice, toast, coffee bean, burnt caramel. Flavor has more of the same, tons of chocolate covered coffee bean, toast, brown sugar, licorice, some dried fruit, a bit nutty too. Full bodied but dry. Very well made.

If I could get away with drinking this as my morning coffee at work, the day would be much brighter. Or much sleepier, considering 3 Sheeps has pushed the 2015 vintage of Joe to 8.0% ABV. The coffee aroma wraps itself around a little chocolate scent and leave you with a smooth, sweet ale. Enjoyed from a bottle.
If you like iced coffee...this is the closest thing in beer form. The lighter/smoother base of the wheat, compared to a stout or porter, really lets the Colectivo roast shine through.

On tap at Happy Gnome. Pours near black with a a light yellowish brown head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of bitter coffee and dark grains supported by roasted malts. Flavor has smooth dark grains with a nice coffee bitterness and a hint of roast.

Dark reddish-black pour with a brown head. Aroma is rich coffee. Taste is coffee, creamy, wheat base, bitterness from the coffee at the end. Burnt flavor also. Very tasty. Nice combination of wheat and coffee.

Tap at Old Fashioned. Unfiltered brown-black body. Not much of a head...soapy beige residue. Massive coffee flavors. Enjoyable. Full coffee blast. Medium to full bodied. Rich, sweet brown sugar tones. Respectable coffee beer.
Bottle thanks to respertFTW. Near black with essentially no head. Dark chocolate and espresso aromas. Similar flavors with some sugar. Deep and rich. Great stuff.

incredible stout by 3 sheeps. tastes like a cup of black coffee to start as well as the finish. very bitter but easy to drink. smells like chocolate and coffee. had a bottle pour at home. black in color with a tan head

Bottled. Poured black with a well-retained, sticky beige head.. looked great! The aroma picked up lots of coffee (sweet and tangy notes) joined by spicy, kind of dank wheat.. you need like coffee to enjoy that smell. The flavor found a wash of cold coffee from the front through the back of the palate.. some meaty wheat and more coffee at the core.. finished with burnt coffee and chocolate joined by a hit of tangy wheat. Medium-bodied, dry, and tangy on the palate.. moderate, rolling carbonation moved it well through the mouth.. tasty stuff.

Malts, coffee, cocoa. Pours nearly black with a slight medium brown foam. Nice flavor of malt, coffee, cocoa. This so not a spiced/herb beer in my tasting. In fact beeradvocate categorizes this beer as a American Dark Wheat Ale which I believe is accurate. Nice palate finish and a really nice beer.

Taster on tap at Old Fashioned in Madison, Wisconsin. Brown color. Nice light brown head. Leaves good thicker lace. Awesome big coffee aroma up front on this, nice mild roast, some light dark chocolate, mild dark fruit. Medium-plus body, full kind of chewy mouthfeel. Light slick texture. Moderate bitter taste, moderate sweet. Great coffee stout! Really like it.
On tap at Three Aces. Poured black with good tan lace. Aroma of roasted choc. Light carb med bod. Sweet boozy choc light resin.
Draft. Huge coffee in the nose, somewhat fruity. Flavor is nuttier toastier coffee, cacao nibs, and its nciely dry. Beaut.

Bottle @ home. Thanks, Jake. Pours dark brown with a small khaki head. Aromas of coffee, copper, and roasted malt. Kind of nutty. A bit of toffee and licorice. Flavor is a bit acidic and heavy on the coffee. A fair amount of roast as well as some dirt and ash. Mild malt sweetness. Not really a fan.
Aroma is strong coffee, malts and spices. The flavor is coffee, spices, mild heat and a malty/wheat finish.
Bottle. Very dark murky brown pour with a small tan head. Tons of coffee in this. Not bitter, but sweet. Smooth fuller palate. Excellent beer!
Bottle. Tons of coffee. Lots of chocolate too. Coffee with cream. Milk chocolatey creamy and super smooth. Not overly roasty. I love coffee beers and this is a Great coffee beer.

bottle actually thanks to me.. damnit dj!?! ... pours a deep brown.. mild head, decent lacing .. . lots of coffee, some easy tar and very light show polish .. . quite nice but could be a bit fuller .. . . i think they should put pies on the fronts of trains, so that when they hit something- its at least a little bit funny.
Bottle thanks to Nathan. Pours a dark amber beige head. The aroma is coffee bean roast. Sweet roast and strong coffee. Light bitter finish. Very good.

Dark brown, almost black pour. Huge fresh coffee nose. Flavor is fresh roasted coffee/iced coffee, slightly nutty, with light cocoa, chocolate, and a hint of brown sugar/cream. Lingering bitter roast coffee and faint cocoa. Medium mouthfeel. Stellar coffee brew!
WOW! this one is great...a huge blast of coffee with a sweet, chocolate aftertaste. I definitely agree with those who say it drinks like a stout
This was awesome. Tastes like a particularly good cup of coffee, plus roasted malt and chocolate. Drink it like a stout, even though this is technically a wheat.

Growler pour at Blackbird during MKE beer week 2013. Dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malt and chocolate. Taste is smooth with chocolate, coffee, caramel and a sweet roasty finish with light acidity.

On tap at the source. Pours an opaque black with a tan head. Aroma has heavy roasted coffee, with some choco/caramel underneath. But huge luscious coffee. Taste is of sweet chocolate, coffee and some bitter nut and lactose. Not swinging too sweet or too bitter. Medium bodied, or perhaps even thinner. Very good smell and good taste. This is a nice one!
Had this from draft at uncle mikes highway pub. Everyone at the table loved this. Black with white head. Rich coffee aroma. Rich thick chocolate coffee taste. Like a chocolate shake. Really good
Made with alterra coffee, this was the baad boy with some easy drinking and perfectly balanced coffee. Very well done, this was super smooth. Tap at craft and draft.

On cask at GTMW - Wow...first rate for this one? Pours back with a thin off white head. Nose is mocha, real pungent lightly sweet with no bitter roastiness. Wow--this is in your face coffee and chocolate, and its beautiful. Taste has smooth coffee--no bitterness--with chocolate, light roast, and coffee grounds on the finish. Smooth and thin bodied, but thats fine--I could smell this stuff all day. Wish I saw some rates on this because I feel like lots of people missed a hidden gem!
